title: Introduction to linear algebra
text:
This notes are mainly based on : Linear Algebra and Optimization for Machine Learning


What is Linear Algebra ?
Linear Algebra is the study of linear operations on vector spaces.



Let \(V\) and \(W\) be vector spaces. A function \(f: V \rightarrow W\) is a linear map if for any two vectors \(\textbf{u}\) and \(\textbf{v}\) the mapping is operation preserving, that is, it satisfies these conditions:

Additivity : \(f(\textbf{u} + \textbf{v}) = f(\textbf{u}) + f(\textbf{v})\)
Homogeneity of scalar multiplication : \(f(\lambda \textbf{u}) = \lambda*f(\textbf{u})\)

For example :
Let’s say we have two vectors and a function \(f\): \[
\begin{aligned}
    \begin{split}
        \textbf{a} = [0, 1] \\
        \textbf{b} = [1 ,1] \\
    \end{split} \\
\end{aligned}
\]
And for any vector in two dimensions, we have this function : \(f(\textbf{v}) = f(a,b) = (3a,b)\)
This functions is operation preserving because, for example : \[
\begin{array}{3,1}
    f(a+b) = f([0,1] + [1,1]) = f([1,2]) = (3,2)\\
    \text{is equal to : }\\
    f(a) + f(b) = [0,1] + [3,1] = [3,2]
\end{array}
\]
It preserves the multiplication, for example, when \(\lambda = 2\): \[
\begin{array}{}
    f(\lambda * \textbf{b} ) = f(2*[1,1]) = f([2,2]) = [6,2]\\
    \text{Which is the same as :} \\
    \lambda * f(\textbf{b} ) = 2 * [3,1] = [6,2]
\end{array}
\]



\(\textbf{v} \rightarrow c\textbf{v}\) with an scalar c centered in the origin of the vector space of \(\textbf{v}\)
The identiy operation
\(\textbf{x} \rightarrow A\textbf{x}\). With \(\textbf{x} \in \mathbb{R}^n \text{ (column vector)}\) and \(A\) a (\(m * n\)) matrix.

A matrix can be seen as a series of linear operations, for example, the scaling matrix: \[
A = \begin{bmatrix}
3 & 0\\
0 & 3
\end{bmatrix}
\] Can be seen as : \[
A = \begin{bmatrix}
f_{1}\\
f_{2}
\end{bmatrix}
\]
With : \(f_{1}(a,b) = 3*a + 0*b\) and \(f_{2}(a,b) = 0*a + 3*b\)
For the vector \(\textbf{c} = [2,1]\). The operation \(A\textbf{c}\) would yield : \[
A\textbf{c} = \begin{bmatrix}
f_{1}(\textbf{c})\\
f_{2}(\textbf{c})
\end{bmatrix}  = \begin{bmatrix}
f_{1}(2,1)\\
f_{2}(2,1)
\end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix}
3*2 + 0 * 1 \\
0*2 + 3 * 1
\end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix}
6 \\
3
\end{bmatrix}
\]




\(x \rightarrow x²\)
\(x \rightarrow x + 1\)





A Vector space is a set of vectors that support addition and scaling.
For example, the set of all Cartesian Coordinates : \(\text{ any } \textbf{v} \in \mathbb{R}²\) with respect to the same origin ([0,0] for example).
